coredata.dc:title: A CAS SCF study of the iron-oxo-porphyrin π radical cation: Similarity in FeO electronic structure between peroxidase compounds I and II
coredata.dc:creator: Yamamoto, Shigeyoshi
Kashiwagi, Hiroshi
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
CAS SCF (complete active space SCF) calculations have been carried out on the ion-oxo-porphine π radical cation, which is a model for peroxidase compound I and catalase compound II. It is found that the electronic structure of the FeO bond is unchanged by removal of an electron from a porphine π orbital. Calculated Mössbauer spectral parameters and the spin population of the FeO moiety are consistent with experiment.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 145, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 25 March 1988 A CAS SCF STUDY OF THE IRON-OXO-PORPHYRIN n RADICAL CATION: SIMILARITY IN Fe-O ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE BETWEEN PEROXIDASE COMPOUNDS I AND II Shigeyoshi YAMAMOTO and Hiroshi KASHIWAGI Institute for Molecular Science, Myodaiji, Okazaki 444, Japan Received 14 December 1987; in final form 13 January 1988 CAS SCF (complete active space SCF) calculations have been carried out on the ion-oxo-porphine it radical cation, which is a model for peroxidase compound I and catalase compound II. It is found that the electronic structure of the Fe O bond is un- changed by removal of an electron from a porphine it orbital. Calculated Mossbauer spectral parameters and the spin population of the Fe O moiety are consistent with experiment. 1. Introduction z Peroxidase and catalase are heme-containing en- zymes which catalyze substrate oxidation by hydro- gen or alkyl peroxides [1]. The intermediates, called compounds I and II [1], play an important role in their enzymatic reactions. The active site of com- pound II is described as iron(IV)-oxo-porphyrin. Compound lis its it radical cation, that is, one elec- tron is removed from a porphyrin it orbital of neu- tral compound II. Understanding the electronic structure of the Fe O bond in these compounds is important for the study of heme-mediated oxygen activation. We demonstrated in a previous paper, paper! [2], that the electronic structure of compound II is not well described in the RHF (restricted Hartree Fock) approximation. Electron correlation is important to obtain a reliable picture for the electronic structure of compound II. For this reason, we carried out CAS SCF (complete active space self-consistent-field) calculations on a model of compound II, FeP (py)O (P =porphine, py = pyridine) to elucidate its elec- tronic structure. CAS SCF is one of the formulations of MC SCF (muiticonfiguration self-consistent-field) [3] proposed by Roos et aI. [4]. The geometry of the calculated model compound is given in fig. 1. The CAS SCF value for the equilibrium Fe O bond dis- tance, 1.66 A, is close to the observed value of 1.64 Fig. I. Geometry assumed for both compound I and II models. The pyridine molecule lies in the xz plane. A [5]. The other calculated properties, such as the stretching frequency and Mossbauer spectrum pa- rameters are also in good agreement with experiment. As mentioned above, CAS SCF is a powerful the- oretical method of accounting for non-dynamical electron correlation effects [6]. This is because all possible electronic configurations among a set of ac- tive orbitais are considered with optimized MOs (molecular orbitais). We extended our CAS SCF O 009-2614/88/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 111 o Xb~ e y Volume 145, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 March 1988 study to compound I to investigate the electronic structure of its Fe O bond. Many experiments indicate that the electronic structure around the Fe O bond does not change even after an electron is removed from a porphyrin it orbital. X-ray crystallographic studies revealed that the it cations of Zn [71 and Mg [81 porphyrins have geometries and electronic distributions for the metal oxygen moiety similar to those of the corre- sponding neutrals. EXAFS spectroscopy [6] has provided evidence for ligation of oxygen to the iron atom in HRP (horseradish peroxidase) compounds I and II and suggested a similar Fe environment in compounds I and II. Mossbauer spectrum parame- ters, IS (isomer shift) and QS (quadrupole split- ting), etc., were measured for HRP compounds I and II [9,10] and for JRP-a (Japanese-radish peroxidase a) compounds I and II [li]. Their observed values are similar and show a characteristic pattern for fer- ry1 iron-porphyrins (IS~O.l mm/s, QS~ 1.0 mm/s). It is important to confirm whether the similarity of experimental data between compounds I and II is accidental or not. The electronic structure of com- pound I has been studied by a variety of theoretical methods [12 161. In the UHF/INDO calculations of Loew et al. [151, the calculated spin population around the Fe O bond shows no significant differ- ence between compounds I and II. This calculation is, however, at the semi-empirical level. Strich et al. [16] performed ab initio UHF calculations, but they scarcely discussed the electron distribution around the Fe O bond. The primary purpose of our study is to investigate the electronic distribution around the Fe O bond of compound I at the ab initio level with the inclusion of correlation effects and to investigate whether the electronic structure of the Fe O bond compounds I and II is similar. 2. Method of calculation The basis set used is the same as that used in paper I. It is a partial-double basis which is double zeta for Fe, valence double for O and N, and minimal with scale factors for C and H. The molecular geometry of the model complex is given in fig. 1. The same geometry is used for both compounds I and II. The molecular symmetry is C2~. The Fe O and Fe N~~ (N~~ =pyridine nitrogen) bond distances are 1.7 and 2.2 A, respectively. These distances were determined by minimizing the total energy of the compound Il model in paper I. Since the porphyrin ring has two nearly degenerate it orbitais with a2~ and a1~ symmetry in the D4h no- tation, there exist two kinds of porphyrin cations, i.e. a2~ and a1~ it cations. The a1~ it orbital has nodes on the porphyrin nitrogens, but the a2~ does not. Since the precise nature of the stable cation is not known 117 191, we did calculations on both cations, choos- ing FeP~ (py)O as a model complex of compound I. CAS SCF calculations were carried out using the program JASON2 [201, which was developed in our laboratory based on Roos super-Cl formalism [4]. The following seven orbitais were chosen as active orbitais; the Fe O a, a*, ~ it~, it~ and ir~ orbitais and the porphine it orbital from which the electron is removed. Among the above seven active orbitals, nine active electrons are distributed in all possible ways consistent with the given overall symmetry. We call this calculation scheme CAS SCF-7. Since there are three unpaired electrons (in the Fe O it orbitals and the porphine it orbital) the spin eigenvaiue of this system is 3/2. The total number of CSFs (con- figuration state functions) amounts to 55 for the a2~ and 64 for the ~ cation. All calculations were carried Out on the HITAC S- 810/10 and M-680H computers at the Computer Center of the Institute for Molecular Science. The program JAMOL3 [21] was used for integral eval- uation and RHF calculations. 3. Results and discussion The occupation numbers and the total energy ob- tained from the CAS SCF calculations are given in table 1. For the compound II model, results of the CAS SCF-6 calculations with six active orbitais (Fe U es, es*, it and m ~ orbitals) are presented. The CAS SCF active orbitais of the Fe O moiety in com- pound I are depicted in fig. 2. They have almost the same shapes as those of compound II given in paper 1. The Fe O ci (a*) orbital has d~2(Fe) 2p(O) character. The Fe O it (it k) orbitais have d~ ( Fe) 2p,~ (O) character. These it orbitais are localized in the Fe O region and extend almost equally over 112 Volume 145, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETFERS 25 March 1988 Table I Occupation number and total energy (au) MO a) Compound! model (CAS SCF-7) Compound II model (CAS SCF-6) a2, cation a1, cation Po a2, 0.999 2 2 Pea1, 2 1.000 2 1.871 1.869 1.868 ~* 0.133 0.135 0.136 1.893 1.894 1.896 1c~ 1.106 1.104 1.102 1c~ 1.893 1.895 1.898 ic~ 1.105 1,103 1.101 numberofCSFs 64 56 28 total energy 2562.3483 2562.3503 2562.5888 a)pO=pO~p~m~~ orbital, a=2pr(O) + d~2(Fe), ~*=d~1 (Fe) 2p~(O),it~=2p~(O) +d~(Fe), it~=d~(Fe) 2p~(O).Thepius and minus signs denote in-phase and anti-phase mixing, respectively. Fig. 2. Contour maps of the CAS SCF active orbitals of the Fe O moiety in the a2, radical cation. The Fe O x~, and it~ orbitais have almost identical shapes to the ir~, and ir~ orbitals, respectively. These contour maps are drawn in the xz plane containing the pyridine molecule. The active orbitals of the a1, cation are very similar to these MOs. (a) a (b) a o o (c) m (d) Trx* 113 Wavefunct ion Gross AO population Gross atomic charge Fe O Fe O d~2_~1 d~2 dyy d~. d~. 2Pz 2Px 2Py compound I model a2,cation a1,cation 1.98 0.75 0.24 1.98 0.75 0.24 1.45 1.44 1.44 1.43 1.34 1.34 1.52 1.54 1.54 1.55 +2.25 +2.28 0.43 0.45 compound II model 1.98 0.76 0.26 1.42 1.41 1.34 1.56 1.57 +2.28 0.49 Wavefunction Gross AO spin population Gross atomic spin population Fe O Fe O &2_y2 d,2 dyy d~ 2p~ 2p~ 2p~, compound I model a20cation a1, cation 0.00 0.03 0.00 0.00 0.02 0.00 0.53 0.54 0.54 0.56 0.00 0.00 0.45 0.43 0.43 0.42 1.10 1.13 0.89 0.86 compoundllmodel 0.00 0.03 0.00 0.56 0.58 0.00 0.41 0.40 1.17 0.82 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 March 1988 Volume 145, number 2 Table 2 Gross AO population, gross atomic charge, gross AO spin population and gross atomic spin population around Fe O for CAS SCF wavefunctions compound I model (CAS SCF-7) RHF spin population on oxygen is far too small and unpaired electrons are markedly polarized towards iron. It is clear that the RHF result is not reliable and that electronic correlation is important. Table 1 shows that the occupation numbers of the compound I model are similar to those of the com- pound II model. This is explained by the similarity in the configuration mixing of the wavefunctions. The dominant configurations and their weights are given in table 3. The similarity of the wavefunctions among the three models is clear from table 3. The most dominant configuration, with a weight of 0.837 is ~ As discussed in paper!, the ox- idation number of central metal is connected with the difference between the number of valence elec- trons in the neutral metal atom and the number of electrons in anti-bonding or non-bonding orbitals which have a certain amount of metal d component. By means of this method, the most dominant con- figuration is assigned to the ferryl structure, Fe (IV). The next dominant configuration represents two- both iron and oxygen. The covalent character of the Fe O bond is revealed in the shapes of these MOs. The result of the Mulliken population analysis is given in table 2. The gross atomic spin population is nearly unity for both iron and oxygen. This means that the two unpaired electrons on the Fe O moiety are distributed over iron and oxygen. Roberts et al. [22] have estimated the hfs coupling tensor for the Fe-O moiety in HRP-I by means of ENDOR. The axial symmetry of the hfs tensor indicates that the Fe O bond axis lies perpendicular to the porphine plane. Their estimated spin populations are 0.25 for both the O 2p~ and 2p~, orbitais. Their numerical ac- curacy is not so high because these values were de- rived from the ENDOR spectra with several approximations. The CAS SCF spin populations on the oxygen p~ orbitals are 0.43 (ps) and 0.42 (pi,). They show axial symmetry and are consistent with the estimation from the ENDOR measurement. In contrast, for RHF, the spin populations are 0.03 for oxygen p~ orbitals and 0.96 for Fe d~ orbitais. The 114 Configuration ~ Weight b) compound I model (CAS SCF-7) compound H model (CAS SCF-6) a2, cation a1, cation main configuration ~ EVE v EtEt eit1_,abict 0EV_ansE, a2~~~o*2 0.837 0.837 0.059 0.057 0.031 0.032 0.031 0.031 0.018 0.019 0.837 0.054 0.037 0.035 0.019 sum of the weights 0.976 0.976 0.982 Wnvefunction IS a) (mm/s) QS b) (mm/s) q u) Sign and direction d) compound I model a2, cation a, cation 0.22 0.21 0.75 0.77 0.01 0.01 +z +z compoundllmodel 0.19 0.95 0.01 +z experimental HRP-I ~ (77 K) HRP-I JRP-acompoundI ~ (77K) 0.00 0.08 0.10 1.20 1.25 1.33 0.0 +2 DHR-II ~ (77K) JRP-acompoundH~~ (77K) 0.03 0.11 1.36 1.46 0.03 +z Volume 145, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 March 1988 Table 3 Configuration weights in the CAS SCF wavefunctions ~ Notation for the orbitals is the same as in table I. b) The configurations whose weight is larger than 0.01 are listed. All spin couplings arising from a given excitation are included in the weight. u) The main configuration is ~ electron excitation, it~itrit~it ~. The configuration mixing is quite similar to that of an iterative natural orbital CI calculation [23] on the 02 molecule at the long bond distance of 1.64 A rather than that at the equilibrium bond distance 1.207 A. In other words, the electronic structure of the Fe U bond in com- pounds I and II is equivalent to that of an elongated unstable 02 molecule. The similarity in the electron distribution around the iron atom between compounds I and II is also confirmed by the calculated Mossbauer spectral pa- ramcters given in table 4. The characteristics of the ferryl iron-porphyrin (small IS t 0.1 mm/s, + z di- rection of the principal axis of the electric field gra- dient tensor) are reproduced. The Mossbauer spectral parameters are almost identical between compounds I and II. Slight differences appear only in the QS value. The observed QS values of compound I are smaller than those of compound II by 0.16 mm/s for HRP and by 0.13 mm/s for JRP-a. This is repro- duced in the present calculation, i.e. the calculated QS value of compound lis smaller than that of com Table 4 Mossbauer spectral parameters ~ Isomer shift, b) Quadrupole splitting. ~ Asymmetry parameter. cl) Sign and direction of the principal axis of the electric field gradient tensor. ~Ref. 19]. Ref. [10]. ~Ref. [Il]. 115 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS Volume 145, number 2 25 March 1988 References pound II by about 0.2 mm/s. The Mossbauer spectral parameters reflect the electron distribution around the Fe atom, especially the distribution of Fe 3d electrons. We now estimate the contribution of Fe 3d electrons to the difference in the QS values according to the method employed in ref. [24]. QS is defined as follows: where y is a constant and V2~ is the principal com- ponent of the EFG (electric field gradient) tensor and ii is the asymmetry parameter. The value of y has been set at 2.14 [2]. Since the direction of the principal axis of the EFO tensor is / z, the difference in the QS value can be estimated from the diagonal component V~ of the ERl tensor. The contribution of Fe 3d electrons to V~2 is given approximately by V~zr ~n1A1+C, where C is a constant depending on the complex treated and j denotes one of the five 3d orbitals (xi) and n is its occupation number. Since we are con- cerned with the difference in the QS value, C in eq. (2) can be disregarded. A1/<x11r31x1> is deter- mined by the angular dependence of ~ Values are 4 fordXYanddX2.Y2, 4 ford~2andd,~and 4 for d~2. <x11r3 ~) is evaluated from the 3d orbital. n1 can be regarded as the gross atomic orbital popula- lion obtained from the Mulliken population analysis on the CAS SCF natural orbitals. Substituting these values in eq. (2), we obtain 0.11 mm/s as the dif- ference in the QS value. Thus about 60% of the total difference is explained by the small change in d elec- Iron distribution. As is evident from the Mulliken population anal- ysis in table 2, removing an electron from the por- phine iv orbital does not cause a qualitative difference in the electronic structure of the Fe O moiety. A similar electronic distribution is obtained for both compounds I and II. This is consistent with the ex- perimental results as mentioned in section 1. Hence the experimental result for compound!! can be used to interpret the result for compound!, and vice versa, as far as the electronic structure of the Fe O bond is concerned. [1] W.D. head.ce:title: A CAS SCF study of the iron-oxo-porphyrin π radical cation: Similarity in FeO electronic structure between peroxidase compounds I and II

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institute for Molecular Science, Myodaiji, Okazaki 444, Japan

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: CAS SCF (complete active space SCF) calculations have been carried out on the ion-oxo-porphine π radical cation, which is a model for peroxidase compound I and catalase compound II. It is found that the electronic structure of the FeO bond is unchanged by removal of an electron from a porphine π orbital. Calculated Mössbauer spectral parameters and the spin population of the FeO moiety are consistent with experiment.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: S. Yamamoto, J. Teraoka and H. Kashiwagi, J. Chem. Phys., to be published.
